bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Mabel H. Lazear, July 15, 1930

div1.p: Agramonte reports that Columbia University plans an unveiling of a memorial plaque in honor of Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Mabel H. Lazear, July 15, 1930
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K. ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA July 15th, 1930
Mrs. Mabel M. Lazear
#6 Oakvale Ave
Berkeley, Cal.
Dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
The Medical Faculty of Columbia University, some time in the
Fall, will consider my suggestion to have a memorial placque, or tablet,
or some such evident memento, erected in the halls of the Medical School,
in honor to the immortal memory of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, Clas of 1892.
I am informed that it will be favorably acted upon.

I need not tell you that I shall leave nothing undone so as to have this
tribute rendered to him, as I believe that, until the moment of his de-
cease, he was the most important and the best trained member of the Army
Board, in the service of which he met an untimely death.

In order to better carry out my purpose, I am very anxious to obtain
certain data that I cannot get from any other d source than yourself, with
regard to his family history and the early part of his life. His scientif-
ic history we are well acquainted with; he was my classmate, as you may
know, and every moment of our contact at Camp Columbia is still vivid in
my mind, until the moment of his passing away at the hospital, which day
I shall never forget, as long as I live.

Do you know that there is a bronze bust erected to his memory, in a
little park facing our Sanitary Department, here? Reed and Carroll are
also equally represented, but I unveiled Lazear's and made the correspond-
ing address, at the time.

Will you let me know the following:
What does the initial W stand for in the name Jesse W. Lazear?
Date of his birth, and where.
As much of his ancestors as you may know;
Father's and Mother's names
Father's profession or calling;
Date of your wedding and where
Your maiden name
Your parents' names
Your children's names and ages now.

Whatever you may think of interest regarding Lazear's early life,
school training, surroundings in boyhood and adolescence that may have
molded his character, and any other information that you may think per-
tinent.

I am sending you herewith, two pamphlets, in which I had occasion to
refer to his work and influence in the Board, that perhaps you will be
pleased to know. At a recent, (June 22) meeting of the Medical Veterans of
the World War, in Detroit, I made an address to an audience composed of the
members, their wives and daughters; as I referred to the strenuous days
of September 1900, the worry of Carroll's illness, your husband's sacri-
fice and what his loss signified to us, there was not an eye but was moist
with restrained tears and the silence and attention was almost reverential.
My written copy was taken from me and will probably be published in the
“Military Surgeon”. I have repeatedly rebelled against the disdain shown
the “working members” of the Board; also against the appellations “Reed's
(2)
Board”, “Reed's Discovery”, “Reed's Commission”, “Reed's Work”, etc. Mainly
for the reason that Maj. Reed was not on hand when the first series of
cases occurred, Carroll, Dean and Lazear, and he only came back to Cuba
after the latter's death: then, with Gen. Wood's support and our experience,
Carroll's and mine, the rest of the work of the Board was comparatively
easy and clear sailing.

I am writing rather extensively, (and tiresomely, perhaps,) because
in my many visits to the United States I never had opportunity to see you and talk it
over with you.

Thank you in advance for whatever information you may kindly give me,
and with my best wishes for for your, and your children's, happiness and
good health, I remain,
